'''Delfino Codazzi''' (March 7, 1824 in [[Lodi, Lombardy|Lodi]] – July 21, 1873 in [[Pavia]]) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[mathematician]].<ref>E. Beltrami sulle "Memorie per la storia dell'Università di Pavia", serie 13 (1878).</ref><ref>U. Amaldi, in Enciclopedia italiana, app. 1, Rome, (1938), 438.</ref>

He made some important contributions to the [[differential geometry]] of surfaces, such as the [[Gauss–Codazzi equations|Codazzi–Mainardi equations]].

==Biography==
He graduated in mathematics at the [[University of Pavia]], where he was a pupil of [[Antonio Maria Bordoni|Antonio Bordoni]]. For a long period Codazzi taught first at the Ginnasio Liceale of [[Lodi, Lombardy|Lodi]], then at the liceo of [[Pavia]]. Meanwhile, he devoted himself to research in [[differential geometry]].

In 1865,  he was appointed professor of complementary algebra and [[analytic geometry]] at University of Pavia. He remained in his position at Pavia until his death in 1873.

He also obtained results concerning isometric lines, [[Differential geometry of surfaces|geodesic triangles]], [[equiareal map]]ping and the stability of floating bodies.
